questions.question: Which of the following structures is enclosed by the prevertebral fascia in the neck?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cervical sympathetic trunk Explanation: Cervical sympathetic trunk is enclosed by the prevertebral fascia, which surrounds the vertebral column and associated structures. Prevertebral fascia/Lamina prevertebralis: Coronal extension from the internal aspect of the deep cervical fascia that runs anterior to the prevertebral muscles is called the Preethi layer of deep cervical fascia. Definition Thin layer of connective tissue that envelopes the prevertebral muscles and cervical sympathetic trunk. Location Anterior to the vertebral column, extending from the base of the skull to the superior mediastinum where it merges with the ligament of the vertebral column (T3/T4 level). Extension Axillary sheath: The cervical and brachial plexuses form from the nerves deep to the fascia, and as they extend, they pull the prevertebral fascia with them forming axillary sheath Functions Support to the vertebral column and associated muscles. Compartmentalization of various cervical structures which prevents infection spread Protective sheath to brachial plexus and subclavian vessels Clinical Significance Infection Spread: Particularly from the retropharyngeal space, which can lead to serious complications such as mediastinitis. Trapezius muscle (Option A): Enclosed by the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia, not the prevertebral fascia. Internal carotid artery (Option B): Contained within the carotid sheath, not the prevertebral fascia. Thyroid gland (Option D): Enclosed by the pretracheal fascia, not the prevertebral fascia.

questions.question: Which of these form the scalp proper?

options.B: Skin and superficial fascia of the scalp
options.C: Skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia of the scalp
options.D: Skin, superficial fascia, deep fascia, and loose areolar tissue of the scalp

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia of the scalp Explanation: The first three layers of the scalp - surgical layers of the scalp = scalp proper The scalp is made up of five layers: Skin: Hairy and has numerous sweat glands and sebaceous glands Superficial fascia (Connective tissue): Provides a medium for vessels and nerves to pass to the skin Deep fascia in the form of the epicranial aponeurosis or galea aponeurotica with the occipitofrontalis muscle Loose areolar tissue: Provides passage for emissary veins connecting extracranial veins to intracranial venous sinuses Pericranium Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume 3, Page 63-64.

questions.question: All of the following are the contents of the occipital triangle of the neck except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) External jugular vein Explanation: The external jugular vein is a content of the subclavian triangle , not the occipital triangle, a posterior triangle-space on the side of the neck behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Boundaries Anterior: Posterior border of sternocleidomastoid Posterior: Anterior border of trapezius Base: Middle one-third of clavicle Division (by the inferior belly of omohyoid) Occipital part-larger upper part Supraclavicular part or Subclavian part-smaller lower part Division Nerves Vessels Lymph Nodes Occipital Triangle Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) Cutaneous branches of cervical plexus: Lesser occipital nerve Great auricular nerve Anterior cutaneous nerve of neck Supraclavicular nerves Muscular branches: To levator scapulae To trapezius To rhomboids Transverse cervical artery and vein Occipital artery Occipital nodes Supraclavicular nodes Subclavian Triangle Roots and trunks of brachial plexus Nerve to serratus anterior (long thoracic nerve) Nerve to subclavius Suprascapular nerve Subclavian artery and vein Suprascapular artery and vein Transverse cervical artery and termination of the corresponding vein External jugular vein A few members of the supraclavicular chain Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume 3, Page 93-95.

questions.question: Choose the appropriate set of correct statement(s) regarding the triangle shown in the image below (red-shaded region) 1) bounded posteroinferiorly by posterior belly of digastric 2) Floor of the triangle is formed by hyoglossus anteriorly 3) Submental artery runs through anterior part of triangle 4) Carotid artery runs through posterior part of triangle
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) 1,3,4 Explanation: The yellow shaded region is the submandibular/digastric triangle Floor of the triangle is formed by mylohyoid anteriorly and hyoglossus posteriorly; other statements are correct. Digastric triangle: Description: Also known as submandibular triangle Enclosed between two bellies of digastric muscle Attachments: Anteroinferiorly Anterior belly of the digastric muscle Posteroinferiorly Posterior belly of the digastric muscle (Statement 1) and stylohyoid muscle Base Base of the mandible, with an imaginary line from the mandible angle to the mastoid process Apex Intermediate tendon of the digastric muscle Floor: Anteriorly Mylohyoid (Statement 2) Posteriorly Hyoglossus Roof: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: Encloses submandibular lymph nodes Superficial fascia: Platysma, cervical branch of facial nerve, ascending branch of transverse cervical nerve Contents: Anterior part Submandibular salivary gland Submandibular lymph nodes Hypoglossal nerve Facial vein (superficial to gland) Facial artery (deep to gland) Submental artery (Statement 3) Mylohyoid nerve and vessels Posterior part External carotid artery (Statement 4) Carotid sheath and contents: Internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, vagus nerve Structures passing between the external and

questions.question: You notice the following examination being done in ED, all of the following are boundaries of the space containing the palpated structure except
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Anterior belly of digastric Explanation: Carotid artery pulsation is being palpated here, which is present in the carotid triangle . Carotid triangle: Boundaries Anterosuperior: Posterior belly of digastric (vs Option A) ; Stylohyoid (Option B) Anteroinferior : Superior belly of omohyoid (Option C) Posterior: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (Option D) Floor: Thyrohyoid Hyoglossus Middle constrictor Inferior constrictor Contents Carotid arteries: Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery, External carotid artery and its first five branches (superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal and occipital) Carotid sinus and carotid body Internal jugular vein Last three cranial nerves: Vagus nerve, Spinal accessory nerve, Hypoglossal nerve Carotid sheath Ansa cervicalis Cervical part of the sympathetic chain Deep cervical lymph nodes

questions.question: During thyroid surgery, the surgeon retracts the muscles forming the floor of the muscular triangle of neck to access the thyroid gland. Which of the following muscles does he not retract?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Geniohyoid Explanation: Geniohyoid does not contribute to the floor of the muscular triangle of the neck. Muscular triangle: Location In the anterior region of the neck Boundaries Anterior: Midline of the neck (from hyoid bone to suprasternal notch) Anterosuperior: Superior belly of the omohyoid muscle Posteroinferior: Anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle Floor Sternothyroid, sternohyoid, and thyrohyoid muscles Roof Investing layer: Deep cervical fascia Superficial fascia: Contains the anterior jugular vein and lymph nodes Contents Infrahyoid muscles: Sternohyoid & Omohyoid (superficial) and Sternothyroid & Thyrohyoid (deep) (Option C) Deeper structures: Thyroid gland, trachea, and esophagus Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume 3, Page 107.

questions.question: Image below shows a method of brachial plexus block. Identify the correct set of approaches and the corresponding space in the neck.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Interscalene approach - posterior triangle Explanation: Procedure shown is the interscalene approach for brachial plexus block which is done via the space present between scalene muscles, known as Scalenus triangle or Subclavian triangle , which is a part of the posterior triangle of neck . Blocks in posterior triangle: Brachial plexus block: Approaches Interscalene approach: Difficult to perform Landmark: Transverse process of C6 vertebra Relatively less safe Indication Emergency and elective surgery of the upper extremity

questions.question: You notice the following procedure being done in OT. Choose the appropriate set of incorrect statement(s) regarding the same. 1) Congenital long QT syndrome is an indication in children 2) Can be done to manage Hyperhidrosis and Raynaud’s phenomenon 3) Local anaesthetic is injected superior to longus colli muscle 4) Relatively unsafe procedure 5) Contralateral Horner syndrome is verification for correct placement of block
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) only 5 Explanation: Procedure shown in the image is stellate ganglion block . Ipsilateral horner syndrome is a verification for correct placement of block (not contralateral) (Statement 5) . Other statements are correct. Stellate ganglion is considered an unsafe procedure due to its high risk of injuries to surrounding structures. (Statement 4) Stellate ganglion block: Indications Children: Congenital long QT syndrome , pain syndromes (eg. herpes zoster ophthalmicus) (Statement 1) Adults: Hyperhidrosis, Raynaud’s phenomenon (Statement 2) Procedure Local anesthetic is injected superior to longus colli muscle . (Statement 3) Cervicothoracic (stellate) sympathetic block is identified via USG-guided probe and block given. Verification Ipsilateral Horner syndrome is seen after correct placement of block (vs Statement 5) Complications Injury to vital

questions.question: Patient presented with a painful swelling as shown below. Senior doctor says the pain is due to the underlying fascia. All of the following structures are enclosed by the layer forming this fascia except
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Levator scapulae Explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of parotid gland swelling. Pain is due to the underlying parotid fascia formed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia. Levator scapulae is not enclosed by the investing layer. Parotid fascia: Investing layer splits into two. Superficial layer: Thick and dense, attached to zygomatic arch Deep layer: Thin and attached to styloid process Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: Location Lies deep to the platysma, encircling the neck like a collar Forms the roof of the posterior triangle of the neck Superior Attachments External occipital protuberance Superior nuchal line Mastoid process, styloid process External acoustic meatus Base of the mandible Inferior Attachments Spine of scapula Posterior Attachments Ligamentum nuchae Spine of seventh cervical vertebra (C7) Anterior Attachments Symphysis menti Hyoid bone Enclosed Structures Muscles: Trapezius (Option B) , Sternocleidomastoid Salivary glands: Parotid , Submandibular gland (Option C) Spaces: Suprasternal space of Burns: Sternal heads of bilateral sternocleidomastoid; Jugular venous arch; Interclavicular ligament Supraclavicular space: External jugular vein (Option D) ; Supraclavicular nerves Forms pulleys for digastric and omohyoid tendons Forms roof of anterior and

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of the pretracheal fascia?

options.D: Limiting the spread of infection in the anterior neck

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Surrounding the carotid sheath Explanation: Pretracheal fascia does not surround the carotid sheath. Pretracheal fascia/Middle cervical fascia/Porter’s fascia: Thin layer of deep fascia limited to anterior part of the neck and is a coronal extension from internal surface of the investing layer, that encloses the thyroid gland and stretches in front of trachea. It can be divided into two layers: Muscular Layer: Encloses the infrahyoid muscles (strap muscles) such as the sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid. Visceral Layer: Encloses the thyroid gland, trachea and esophagus. Attachments: Superiorly : Attached to the hyoid bone. Inferiorly : Extends to the upper thorax and blends with the fibrous pericardium. Laterally : Blends with the carotid sheath, though it does not enclose the structures within the sheath. Functions : Support : Provides structural support for the thyroid gland, trachea, and esophagus. (Option A & B) Infection Control : Helps limit the spread of infections within the neck, particularly in the anterior compartment. (Option D) Facilitates Movement: Allows for movement of the thyroid gland and trachea during swallowing and breathing.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe neck pain, difficulty swallowing, and fever. A CT scan reveals a deep neck infection that has spread into the mediastinum. Which anatomical space is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Retropharyngeal space Explanation : Retropharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull down to the posterior mediastinum. Infections in this space can easily spread to the mediastinum, leading to mediastinitis . Classification of Spaces: Suprahyoid spaces: Located above the hyoid bone, including the submandibular and prevertebral spaces. Infrahyoid spaces: Located below the hyoid bone, typically related to deeper neck structures. Suprahyoid spaces: Submental space Deep to upper investing layer of deep cervical fascia, superficial to mylohyoid muscles Submandibular space Deep to the concerned half of the mandible, between the anterior and posterior bellies of the digastric muscle Sublingual space Deep to mylohyoid muscles in the floor of the mouth, continuous with the opposite side Peritonsillar space Part of intrapharyngeal space, around palatine tonsils between pillars of fauces Parapharyngeal space On either side of the posterolateral aspect of pharynx Medially - superior constrictor of pharynx Laterally - medial pterygoid Retropharyngeal space Anteriorly - buccopharyngeal fascia of pharynx Posteriorly - prevertebral layer Laterally - carotid sheath Superiorly - cranial base Infrahyoid Spaces: Pretracheal space Behind pretracheal fascia and infrahyoid muscles, in front of the anterior wall of esophagus. Retrovisceral space Between the posterior wall of pharynx/esophagus and prevertebral fascia. Prevertebral space Between prevertebral fascia and vertebral column. Carotid space Around the contents of carotid sheath, demarcated by parts of investing, pretracheal, and prevertebral layers. Parapharyngeal space (Option A): While this space is adjacent to the pharynx and can be a site of infection, it does not communicate directly with the mediastinum. Carotid space (Option B): This space contains the carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve but is not typically involved in spreading infections to the mediastinum. Prevertebral space (Option D): Infections here can affect the vertebrae or muscles but are less likely to spread to the mediastinum compared to the retropharyngeal space.

questions.question: Which of the following structures is not the content of carotid sheath?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) External jugular vein Explanation : Carotid Sheath: Condensation of the connective tissue around the great vessels of the neck, forming a tubular sheet of fascia. Contents Common carotid artery Internal carotid artery Internal jugular vein Vagus nerve. Anatomical Details The carotid sheath extends from the upper border of the thyroid cartilage down to the bifurcation of the carotid arteries. The internal jugular vein is lateral to the carotid artery; the vagus nerve is located between and posterior to the vessels. Anteriorly The carotid sheath is covered by the pretracheal fascia. Posteriorly The carotid sheath is bordered by the prevertebral fascia. Reference: Inderbir Singh's Textbook of Anatomy, 6th Edition, Volume 3, Page 123.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about parotid gland is true?

options.A: The parotid duct passes through the masseter muscle.
options.B: The parotid gland is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII).
options.C: The parotid gland is located anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
options.D: The parotid gland primarily secretes mucous saliva.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The parotid duct passes through the masseter muscle. Explanation: Parotid gland : Largest salivary gland is located on each side of the face anterior to the ears and is made up of two lobes, a superficial lobe, and a deep lobe. Located in the retromandibular fossa. The superficial lobe lies lateral to the facial nerve and overlies the lateral surface of the masseter muscle. The deep lobe lies medial to the facial nerve and is situated between the mastoid process of the temporal bone and the mandibular ramus. A fascial capsule called the parotid sheath surrounds the parotid gland. The duct of the parotid gland, also termed the Stensen duct , runs across the masseter muscle and exits into the oral cavity at the level of the upper second molar. The parotid gland is supplied by the external carotid artery and its branches and drained by the external jugular vein.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man is scheduled for a parotidectomy due to a tumor in the parotid gland. The surgeon reviews the anatomical relationships to avoid damage to surrounding structures. Which of the following structures is located superiorly to the parotid gland?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Zygomatic arch Explanation: Zygomatic arch is located superiorly to the parotid gland. Relations to parotid gland Anteriorly Masseter muscle Buccal fat pad Posteriorly External ear Mastoid process Sternocleidomastoid muscle Medially Styloid process and associated muscles (styloglossus, stylohyoid, digastric) Carotid artery and internal jugular vein Cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal), X (vagus), and XI (accessory) Mandibles ramus Laterally Skin and superficial fascia Inferiorly Angle of the mandible Submandibular gland Superiorly Zygomatic arch

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the structures within the parotid gland are accurate? The external carotid artery enters the parotid gland through the posteromedial surface. The maxillary artery exits through the posterior surface of the gland. The superficial temporal artery branches into the transverse facial artery and emerges from the anterior part of the superior surface. The superficial temporal vein and maxillary vein unite to form the retromandibular vein, which divides into anterior and posterior divisions near the apex of the gland. The facial nerve enters the parotid gland and passes behind the retromandibular vein.
questions.explanation: anteromedial surface, not the posterior surface. The facial nerve enters the parotid gland at the posteromedial surface, passing in front of the retromandibular vein, not behind it. Structures Within the Parotid Gland Arteries External Carotid Artery: Enters through the posteromedial surface. Maxillary Artery: Exits through the anteromedial surface. Superficial Temporal Artery : Branches into the transverse facial artery and emerges from the anterior part of the superior surface. Veins Superficial Temporal Vein and Maxillary Vein unite to form the Retromandibular Vein , which divides into anterior and posterior divisions near the apex of the gland. Facial Nerve Exits the skull through the Stylomastoid Foramen, enters the parotid gland at the posteromedial surface , passing in front of the retromandibular vein and external carotid artery. Divides into Temporofacial and Cervicofacial branches near the neck of the mandible, further branching into five terminal branches: Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Marginal Mandibular, and Cervical, exiting along the anterior border and apex of the gland. Lymphatics Contains parotid lymph nodes located in the superficial fascia and deep to the deep fascia over the gland. Parotid Duct/ Stensen's Duct About 5 cm long. Origin: Emerges from the middle of the parotid gland's anterior border. Course: Runs forward over the masseter muscle, then makes a medial turn at the masseter's anterior border. Structures Pierced: Buccal Pad of Fat Buccopharyngeal Fascia Buccinator Muscle (penetrates obliquely) Termination: After passing through the buccinator, the duct travels briefly between the buccinator and oral mucosa, then opens into the vestibule of the mouth opposite the upper second molar's crown. This oblique passage prevents the duct from inflating with air when blowing.
